body:
You're most welcome :) There was a bunch of chances related with this in 0.4.4 and 0.4.5. Could you [upgrade to 0.4.5.](https://github.com/autonomio/talos/wiki/Installation-Options#install-from-weekly) and see if that resolves your issue. 

Related with the ability to get the best_params in a dictionary, it's a good idea to be able to get a list of dictionaries with the best params for human readability. I'll create a new issue for that.

issue.title: human readable format for best parameters

labels.name: topic: documentation
labels.description: better doc strings or comments needed

milestone.title: v.0.6.2
milestone.description: This update will consist of fixes and upgrades to the v0.6 strain Talos, but the main focus will be on publishing the new comprehensive and up-to-date documentation on a new docs platform (docsify).

repository.name: talos
repository.description: Hyperparameter Optimization for TensorFlow, Keras and PyTorch

issue.body: As per #146 let's add a list of dictionaries format for best_params in addition to the current (which is for the purpose of feeding it directly into the experiment programmatically).

body: I think this should be resolved in the latest version, so closing here.

For me, it is not resolved. I installed the latest talos version this Monday with
`pip3 install git+https://github.com/autonomio/talos@daily-dev`

and unfortunately, the same problem occurs. How can I help to resolve that problem?

@felixriese can you try one of the examples https://github.com/autonomio/talos/tree/dev#examples

Maybe to be safe, create a new environment and try the example then.

I checked it out, and there are some issues with the examples in the new README.md. I'll have to sort it out before it makes it to master. 

For now, I had created a template for first line troubleshooting: 

https://github.com/autonomio/talos/wiki/First-Line-Troubleshooting-(no-conda)

What do you get when you follow that?

**Troubleshooting example:** It is not working, misses matplotlib and after `pip install matplotlib`, there is an input error `ImportError: Python is not installed as a framework. ...`.

**Guess:** Is it possible that this problem only occurs for functional keras models? It worked with other models before and I am figuring out the difference between these models at the moment.

@mikkokotila Yes, Mac OSX. It says `talos==0.4.5` in the env of the troubleshooting example.

The error occurred on the `tensorflow/tensorflow:1.12.0-gpu-py3`, maybe that helps in the meantime.

As a first measure, can you update to 0.4.6 that is available in dev and daily-dev now. This should not change anything regarding the issue we are tracking down, but it is a good measure nevertheless. 

Are you by any chance on Jupyter? If yes, what do you get with:

`print(talos.__version__)`

...because sometimes jupyter uses another python (and different packages) than the env where you launch it.
In my docker, I've installed the latest version `0.4.6` when the problem occurred.

And is that the version you can verify to be in use by the Jupyter (in case you are using it)? Also what is your python version (is it 2 like the @toddpi314 )? 

At this point, could you also share a link to a [dump](https://pastebin.com/) with the csv you get after Scan() finish and a link to a screenshot that shows the error in the dataframe you get from Reporting().

Python version 3.5.2 in the docker.

Dict:
```python
    p = {
        "conv1_filt": [16, 32],
        "conv2_filt": [32, 64],
        "conv3_filt": [64, 128],
        "conv4_filt": [64, 128],
        "kernel_size": [3],
        "activation": ["relu"],
        "padding": ["same", "valid"],
        "fc1_units": [128],
        "fc2_units": [128],
        "losses": ["categorical_crossentropy"],
        "optimizer": ["adam", "nadam"],
        "batch_size": [16, 32, 128],
        "epochs": [40, 120],
    }
```

First 3 lines of the CSV-file:
```csv
round_epochs,val_loss,val_acc,acc,loss,kernel_size,conv4_filt,epochs,conv2_filt,activation,fc1_units,batch_size,losses,conv1_filt,conv3_filt,optimizer,fc2_units,padding
40,0.7091530537674303,0.7073013831197199,0.7286607234592087,0.6670888108251427,3,64,32,relu,32,categorical_crossentropy,40,16,128,128,128,same,adam
120,0.6819279710074719,0.7365712447924107,0.8191413053822256,0.44182159027514345,3,64,64,relu,32,categorical_crossentropy,120,32,128,128,128,valid,nadam
```

The  `Reporting()` is working without error, the output after
```
r = ta.Reporting("file.csv")
r.data
```
is the dataframe with exactly the structure of the CSV-file. -> The wrong order.

Got it. I think that this is something else than the OP case. I have not seen such error before (I've seen where the column and label is off by one but here that's clearly not the case). 

Can you share small amount of data, or data in the same shape / type as the one you are inputting to the model, as well as your Scan command. I will try to replicate this, and try to get this fixed ASAP. I usually spend time every morning on Talos issues/fixes so it might be I can take care of it tomorrow. 

Thanks a lot for taking the time for the back and forth. No doubt we are close to resolving this for you (and getting rid of any underlying issues that are causing this).

**Data:**
* `X_train, X_val`: The shape of each datapoint is (256,) with values between 0 and 1 (maybe generate them with np.random.rand for testing) and I train with about 10000 datapoints.
* `y_train, y_val`: I perform a classification with 4 classes and I use the LabelBinarizer from sklearn. The y-data therefore has a shape of (4,) with one value 1 and three values 0.

**Scan:**
```python
from keras.models import Model
from keras.layers import Dense, Input, Conv1D, MaxPooling1D, Flatten
import talos as ta

def mymodel(x_train, y_train, x_val, y_val, params):
    kernel_size = int(params["kernel_size"])
    activation = params["activation"]
    padding = params["padding"]

    inp = Input(shape=(x_train.shape[1], 1))
    x = Conv1D(filters=int(params["conv1_filt"]),
               kernel_size=kernel_size,
               activation=activation,
               padding=padding)(inp)
    x = MaxPooling1D(2)(x)
    x = Conv1D(filters=int(params["conv2_filt"]),
               kernel_size=kernel_size,
               activation=activation,
               padding=padding)(x)
    x = MaxPooling1D(2)(x)
    x = Conv1D(filters=int(params["conv3_filt"]),
               kernel_size=kernel_size,
               activation=activation,
               padding=padding)(x)
    x = MaxPooling1D(2)(x)
    x = Conv1D(filters=int(params["conv4_filt"]),
               kernel_size=kernel_size,
               activation=activation,
               padding=padding)(x)
    x = MaxPooling1D(2)(x)
    x = Flatten()(x)
    x = Dense(int(params["fc1_units"]), activation=activation)(x)
    x = Dense(int(params["fc2_units"]), activation=activation)(x)
    x = Dense(4, activation="softmax")(x)
    model = Model(inputs=inp, outputs=x)

    model.compile(loss=params["losses"],
                  optimizer=params["optimizer"],
                  metrics=['accuracy'])

    out = model.fit(x_train, y_train,
                    batch_size=int(params["batch_size"]),
                    epochs=int(params["epochs"]),
                    validation_data=(x_val, y_val),
                    verbose=0,
                    )

    return out, model

p = {
    "conv1_filt": [16, 32],
    "conv2_filt": [32, 64],
    "conv3_filt": [64, 128],
    "conv4_filt": [64, 128],
    "kernel_size": [3],
    "activation": ["relu"],
    "padding": ["same", "valid"],
    "fc1_units": [128],
    "fc2_units": [128],
    "losses": ["categorical_crossentropy"],
    "optimizer": ["adam", "nadam"],
    "batch_size": [16, 32, 128],
    "epochs": [40, 120],
}

h = ta.Scan(x=X_train, y=y_train, params=p,
            dataset_name="datasetname",
            experiment_no="1",
            model=mymodel,
            x_val=X_val, y_val=y_val
            )
```

What else do you need?
Ah, sorry my mistake, I also need the input Keras model of course :)

Thanks for the co-operation. I've tested your model and it produces exactly the right h.data (the Scan() object dataframe) and exactly the right csv. 

I'm almost sure there is something in your system that refers to a wrong talos version. If you can create an AWS/google instance, you would be able to verify this easily by running your code there. 

Here is the code I've used to generate the data that is accepted by your model. As the first step, you could try it with your model in the system that yields the issue. Just to eradicate the doubt that the input data would somehow effect the headings.

```
import numpy as np
from keras.utils import to_categorical

data = np.random.randint(0, 4, 12)
y_train = to_categorical(data)
y_val = to_categorical(data)

X_train = np.random.random((12, 200))
X_train = X_train.reshape(X_train.shape[0], X_train.shape[1], 1)
X_val = X_train

```
Other than that, I've used your model exactly like you had provided, except for one more thing. I'm using `grid_downsample=0.02` to make the test pass instantly.

Related with this, the most common case I'm aware of is that the model is run on a Jupyter notebook, but the `kernel spec` is messed up. So if you are on Jupyter, then the first thing to do is to make sure that `print(talos.__version__)` yields 0.4.6 when you call it from inside a notebook kernel.
